etymologies: Old English (in sponge (sense 2 of the noun)), via Latin from Greek spongia, later form of spongos, reinforced in Middle English by Old French esponge

definitions: a primitive sedentary aquatic invertebrate with a soft porous body that is typically supported by a framework of fibers or calcareous or glassy spicules. Sponges draw in a current of water to extract nutrients and oxygen.
shortDefinitions: primitive sedentary aquatic invertebrate with soft porous body

definitions: a piece of a soft, light, porous substance originally consisting of the fibrous skeleton of an invertebrate but now usually made of synthetic material. Sponges absorb liquid and are used for washing and cleaning.
shortDefinitions: piece of soft, light, porous absorbent substance originally consisting of fibrous skeleton of aquatic invertebrate but now usually made of synthetic material

definitions: an act of wiping or cleaning with a sponge

examples.text: they gave him a quick sponge down

shortDefinitions: act of wiping or cleaning with sponge

definitions: sponge used as padding or insulating material

examples.text: the headguard is padded with sponge

shortDefinitions: soft, light, porous substance used as padding or instulating material

definitions: a piece of sponge impregnated with spermicide and inserted into a woman's vagina as a form of barrier contraceptive.
shortDefinitions: piece of soft, light, porous substance impregnated with spermicide and inserted into woman's vagina as form of barrier contraceptive

definitions: metal in a porous form, typically prepared by reduction without fusion or by electrolysis

examples.text: the gateau is made with moist sponge

definitions: a steamed or baked pudding of fat, flour, and eggs.
a person who lives at someone else's expense.
shortDefinitions: person who lives at someone else's expense

definitions: wipe, rub, or clean with a wet sponge or cloth

examples.text: she sponged him down in an attempt to cool his fever

shortDefinitions: wipe or clean with wet sponge or cloth

definitions: remove or wipe away (liquid or a mark) with a wet sponge or cloth

examples.text: I'll go and sponge this orange juice off my dress

shortDefinitions: remove or wipe away liquid or mark with sponge or cloth

definitions: give a decorative mottled or textured effect to (a painted wall or surface) by applying a different shade of paint with a sponge

examples.text: she repainted the walls white, then sponged them in turquoise, green, and lilac

shortDefinitions: give decorative effect to painted surface by applying different shade of paint with sponge

definitions: obtain or accept money or food from other people without doing or intending to do anything in return

examples.text: they found they could earn a perfectly good living by sponging off others

shortDefinitions: obtain or accept money or food from other people without doing or intending to do anything in return

definitions: obtain (something) without doing anything in return for it

examples.text: he edged closer, clearly intending to sponge money from her

shortDefinitions: obtain money or food from someone without doing anything in return
